column2: Arrays have a fixed size determined at compile time in most languages.
A stack follows a Last In
In a queue
column3: the element that is added first is also removed first

column2: Binary search can be performed on an unsorted array.
Linked lists are stored in contiguous memory locations.
The time complexity for searching an element in a balanced binary search tree is O(log n).
A graph is considered a tree if it is connected and contains cycles.
Depth First Search (DFS) can be implemented using a queue.
A hash table uses a hash function to map keys to values for faster data retrieval.
A doubly linked list allows traversal in both forward and backward directions.
The average-case time complexity for inserting an element in a binary heap is O(1).
Breadth First Search (BFS) uses a stack to explore nodes.
The worst-case time complexity for accessing an element in an array is O(1).
Binary trees can have at most two children per node.
The space complexity of a linked list is typically more than an array due to extra storage for pointers.
A circular queue can reuse empty spaces by wrapping around the array.
A graph must be connected to perform Depth First Search (DFS).
The height of a balanced binary tree is proportional to the logarithm of the number of nodes.
Sorting a list using Merge Sort has a worst-case time complexity of O(n log n).
In a priority queue
column3: elements are always removed in the order they were added.
